Suddenly, the phone starts ringing. You quickly pick it up and bring it to your ear.
“Hello? Are you the private consultant I’ve heard so much about? Ah, good, I have the right number then. A client of mine has said a lot about you and how effective you are at your job.”
“They claimed that you were one of the best private consultants with expertise in forensics out there, is that true?”
1. [Yes]

column2: “Oh, where are my manners? I am Jim Moore, a detective, and I have need of your assistance in a case I am currently working on. As is standard, I will assume you follow rules of client confidentiality.”
You hear the rustling of papers on the other side of the phone.
“So, I guess I should start with some background details.”
“A day ago, March 7th, the corpse of one Winston Payne, male, 48, was found in a back alleyway between the local general goods store ‘The Good Generals’, and a ceramic ware shop ‘Potter Pots Pots.’”

“From some anonymous citizens, I have learned that he isn’t particularly well off, and works at ‘The Good Generals.’ He works there as a cleaner and cashier, and it was his employer who found him in that alleyway after he failed to get back to the cash register after his lunch break.”
“After some investigation on my own, I have narrowed down our suspects to three people.”

“James Baker, male, 27, owns and runs a family legacy bakery just four blocks away from the crime scene. When I was questioning him, he outright stated that he was not too hung up on Mr. Payne’s demise. He even said ‘good riddance’ afterward.”
“Jagger Carpenter, male, 28, runs a woodwork shop three blocks from the crime scene. When I questioned him, he was highly irritable and bad-tempered.”

“Finally, Andrew Potter, male, 63, a ceramist. The ceramics shop next to the crime scene is his. When I interrogated him, his eyes bore into mine, unblinkingly, and his tone was always rather ... excited shall we say. He just has this very unsettling atmosphere around him, gives me the creeps.”
“All three suspects were seen in close proximity to the alleyway within an hour of the estimated time of murder.”

“Now that I’ve told you the basic details, I’ll get into the details. This is where I need your help. Your expertise in forensics, logical reasoning, and deduction will be crucial for helping me determine who is the true killer of these three.”
“I managed to get in touch with a few anonymous citizens. From them, I got some possible motives for why our suspects would have murdered Mr. Payne.”

“The next clue involves the murder weapon, or rather, lack thereof. The crime scene did not have any objects lying around that indicated use for murderous intent. Instead, we can only deduce the tool of murder from the wounds on Mr. Payne’s body.”

“Mr. Payne’s body has numerous long cuts all over his upper body, including torso, arms, and head. The wounds indicate many slash attacks were used rather than any stab attacks, and that each slash is surprisingly shallow.”
